Javins v. First Nat\u2019l Realty Corp.,.raw_text: Javins v. First Nat’l Realty Corp., 428 F.2d 1071 (D.C. Cir. 1970)
Javins v. First Nat\u2019l Realty Corp.,.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is an implied covenant in residential tenancies recognized and enforced under Massachusetts law and common law principles.

M.G.L. c. 111.proposition: See, e.g., Javins v. First Nat’l Realty Corp., 428 F.2d 1071 (D.C. Cir. 1970) (recognizing the implied warranty of habitability and the covenant of quiet enjoyment as protecting tenants from conditions substantially interfering with residential use); see also Massachusetts statutory and regulatory standards for housing habitability and heating set forth in M.G.L. c. 111, the State Sanitary Code (105 CMR 410.000 et seq.), and other landlord-tenant authorities.

the State Sanitary Code (105 CMR 410.000.raw_text: the State Sanitary Code (105 CMR 410.000 et seq.)
the State Sanitary Code (105 CMR 410.000.proposition: See, e.g., Javins v. First Nat’l Realty Corp., 428 F.2d 1071 (D.C. Cir. 1970) (recognizing the implied warranty of habitability and the covenant of quiet enjoyment as protecting tenants from conditions substantially interfering with residential use); see also Massachusetts statutory and regulatory standards for housing habitability and heating set forth in M.G.L. c. 111, the State Sanitary Code (105 CMR 410.000 et seq.), and other landlord-tenant authorities.

105 CMR 410.000 et seq..proposition: See, e.g., Javins v. First Nat’l Realty Corp., 428 F.2d 1071 (D.C. Cir. 1970) (recognizing the implied warranty of habitability and the covenant of quiet enjoyment as protecting tenants from conditions substantially interfering with residential use); see also Massachusetts statutory and regulatory standards for housing habitability and heating set forth in M.G.L. c. 111, the State Sanitary Code (105 CMR 410.000 et seq.), and other landlord-tenant authorities.

Massachusetts General Laws, Chapter 186.raw_text: Massachusetts General Laws, Chapter 186 (Landlord and Tenant) (general statutory framework applicable to landlord-tenant relationships in Massachusetts).
Massachusetts General Laws, Chapter 186.proposition: Plaintiff relies on and cites the following statutes, regulations and authorities as relevant legal support for the claim of breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, and for the general legal principles concerning landlord obligations, habitability standards, and remedies under Massachusetts law and applicable precedent:

Massachusetts General Laws, Chapter 111.raw_text: Massachusetts General Laws, Chapter 111 (Public Health), and related public health statutes authorizing enforcement of housing standards.
Massachusetts General Laws, Chapter 111.proposition: Plaintiff relies on and cites the following statutes, regulations and authorities as relevant legal support for the claim of breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, and for the general legal principles concerning landlord obligations, habitability standards, and remedies under Massachusetts law and applicable precedent:

State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000.raw_text: State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq. (Minimum Standards of Fitness for Human Habitation) — including provisions governing heating and minimum temperature requirements and landlord responsibilities to maintain heating and habitability.
State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000.proposition: Plaintiff relies on and cites the following statutes, regulations and authorities as relevant legal support for the claim of breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, and for the general legal principles concerning landlord obligations, habitability standards, and remedies under Massachusetts law and applicable precedent:

M.G.L. chapter 186.proposition: Plaintiff specifically invokes the State Sanitary Code (105 CMR 410.000 et seq.) and the landlord-tenant law codified in M.G.L. chapter 186, as well as the common law covenant of quiet enjoyment as recognized and applied in Massachusetts and federal decisions such as Javins and related precedent.

105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq..proposition: Plaintiff specifically invokes the State Sanitary Code (105 CMR 410.000 et seq.) and the landlord-tenant law codified in M.G.L. chapter 186, as well as the common law covenant of quiet enjoyment as recognized and applied in Massachusetts and federal decisions such as Javins and related precedent.
